chapters.title: Measurement
chapters.summary: Chapter 1 introduces the fundamental concepts of measurement, including units, length, time, and mass. It covers the International System of Units, unit conversions, significant figures, and basic definitions of physical quantities.

chapters.title: Motion Along a Straight Line
sections: GRAPHICAL INTEGRATION IN MOTION ANAL YSIS
chapters.summary: Chapter 2 discusses motion along a straight line, covering concepts like position, displacement, velocity (average and instantaneous), speed, and acceleration. It also addresses constant acceleration and free-fall.

chapters.title: Vectors
sections: UNIT VECTORS, ADDING VECTORS BY COMPONENTS
Vectors and the Laws of Physics
chapters.summary: Chapter 3 introduces vectors, their components, and vector operations such as addition and multiplication. It distinguishes between vectors and scalars and discusses unit vectors.

chapters.title: Motion in Two and Three Dimensions
chapters.summary: Chapter 4 extends the concepts of motion to two and three dimensions, covering position, displacement, velocity, acceleration, projectile motion, uniform circular motion, and relative motion.

chapters.title: Force and Motion—I
chapters.summary: Chapter 5 introduces Newton's laws of motion, defining force, mass, and their relationship. It covers Newton's first and second laws, some particular forces, and the application of Newton's laws.

chapters.title: Force and Motion—II
sections: THE DRAG FORCE AND TERMINAL SPEED
The Drag Force and Terminal Speed
chapters.summary: Chapter 6 continues the discussion of force and motion, focusing on friction, drag force, terminal speed, and uniform circular motion.

chapters.title: Kinetic Energy and Work
sections: WORK DONE BY THE GRAVITATIONAL FORCE
Work Done by the Gravitational Force
WORK DONE BY A SPRING FORCE
Work Done by a Spring Force
WORK DONE BY A GENERAL VARIABLE FORCE
Work Done by a General Variable Force
chapters.summary: Chapter 7 introduces the concepts of kinetic energy, work, and power. It covers work done by gravitational force, spring force, and general variable forces.

chapters.title: Potential Energy and Conservation of Energy
sections: WORK DONE ON A SYSTEM BY AN EXTERNAL FORCE
Work Done on a System by an External Force
chapters.summary: Chapter 8 discusses potential energy and the conservation of energy. It covers conservative forces, potential energy curves, and work done by external forces on a system.

chapters.title: Center of Mass and Linear Momentum
sections: NEWTON’S SECOND LAW FOR A S YSTEM OF PARTICLES
Newton’s Second Law for a System of Particles
The Linear Momentum of a System of Particles
MOMENTUM AND KINETIC ENERGY IN COLLIS IONS
Momentum and Kinetic Energy in Collisions
COLLISIONS IN TWO D IMENS IONS
SYSTEMS WITH VARYING MASS: A ROCKET
Systems with Varying Mass: A Rocket
chapters.summary: Chapter 9 introduces the center of mass and linear momentum. It covers Newton's second law for a system of particles, collisions, impulse, conservation of linear momentum, and systems with varying mass like rockets.

chapters.title: Rotation
sections: RELATING THE LINEAR AND ANGULAR VARIABLES
Relating the Linear and Angular Variables
chapters.summary: Chapter 10 covers rotational motion, including rotational variables, constant angular acceleration, the relationship between linear and angular variables, kinetic energy of rotation, rotational inertia, torque, and Newton's second law for rotation.

chapters.title: Rolling, Torque, and Angular Momentum
sections: ROLLING AS TRANSLATION AND ROTATION COMBINED
Rolling as Translation and Rotation Combined
FORCES AND KINETIC ENERGY OF ROLLING
NEWTON’S SECOND LAW IN ANGULAR FORM
Newton’s Second Law in Angular Form
ANGULAR MOMENTUM OF A RIGID BODY
The Angular Momentum of a System of Particles
The Angular Momentum of a Rigid Body Rotating About a Fixed Axis
chapters.summary: Chapter 11 discusses rolling motion as a combination of translation and rotation. It covers the kinetic energy of rolling, forces of rolling, torque, angular momentum, Newton's second law in angular form, conservation of angular momentum, and precession of a gyroscope.

chapters.title: Equilibrium and Elasticity
chapters.summary: Chapter 12 covers equilibrium and elasticity, including the requirements of equilibrium, the center of gravity, examples of static equilibrium, indeterminate structures, and elasticity.

chapters.title: Gravitation
sections: GRAVITATION AND THE PRINCIPLE OF SUPERPOSITION
Gravitation and the Principle of Superposition
chapters.summary: Chapter 13 discusses gravitation, including Newton's law of gravitation, the principle of superposition, gravitation near Earth's surface and inside Earth, gravitational potential energy, Kepler's laws, satellite orbits and energy, and Einstein's theory of gravitation.

chapters.title: Fluids
chapters.summary: Chapter 14 introduces fluids, density, and pressure. It covers fluids at rest and methods for measuring pressure.

chapters.title: Oscillations
chapters.summary: Chapter 15 covers oscillations, including simple harmonic motion, energy in simple harmonic motion, angular simple harmonic oscillators, pendulums, circular motion, damped simple harmonic motion, and forced oscillations and resonance.

chapters.title: Waves—I
sections: WAVE SPEED ON A STRETCHED STRING

ENERGY AND POWER OF A WAVE TRAVELING ALONG 
A STRING
chapters.summary: Chapter 16 discusses waves, including transverse waves, wave speed on a stretched string, energy and power of a wave traveling along a string, the wave equation, interference of waves, phasors, and standing waves and resonance.

chapters.title: Waves—II
chapters.summary: Chapter 17 covers sound waves, including the speed of sound, traveling sound waves, interference, intensity and sound level, sources of musical sound, beats, the Doppler effect, and supersonic speeds and shock waves.

chapters.title: Temperature, Heat, and the First Law of Thermodynamics
chapters.summary: Chapter 18 discusses temperature, heat, and the first law of thermodynamics. It covers temperature scales, thermal expansion, heat absorption, the first law of thermodynamics, and heat transfer mechanisms.

chapters.title: The Kinetic Theory of Gases
sections: THE MOLAR SPECIFIC HEATS OF AN IDEAL GAS
DEGREES OF FREEDOM AND MOLAR SPECIFIC HEATS
THE ADIABATIC EXPANSION OF AN IDEAL GAS
chapters.summary: Chapter 19 covers the kinetic theory of gases, including Avogadro's number, ideal gases, pressure, temperature and RMS speed, translational kinetic energy, mean free path, distribution of molecular speeds, molar specific heats, degrees of freedom, and adiabatic expansion.

chapters.title: Entropy and the Second Law of Thermodynamics
sections: ENTROPY IN THE REAL WORLD: ENGINES
chapters.summary: Chapter 20 discusses entropy and the second law of thermodynamics, covering irreversible processes, entropy changes, engines, refrigerators, and a statistical view of entropy.

chapters.title: Coulomb’s Law
chapters.summary: Chapter 21 introduces Coulomb's Law, electric charge, conductors and insulators, quantization of charge, and conservation of charge.

chapters.title: Electric Fields
sections: THE ELECTRIC FIELD DUE TO A CHARGED PARTICLE
THE ELECTRIC FIELD DUE TO A DIPOLE
THE ELECTRIC FIELD DUE TO A LINE OF CHARGE
THE ELECTRIC FIELD DUE TO A CHARGED DISK
A POINT CHARGE IN AN ELECTRIC FIELD
A DIPOLE IN AN ELECTRIC FIELD
chapters.summary: Chapter 22 covers electric fields, including the electric field due to a charged particle, dipole, line of charge, and charged disk. It also discusses the behavior of a point charge and a dipole in an electric field.

chapters.title: Gauss’ Law
chapters.summary: Chapter 23 discusses Gauss' Law, including electric flux, Gauss' Law and Coulomb's Law, charged isolated conductors, and applications of Gauss' Law to cylindrical, planar, and spherical symmetries.

chapters.title: Electric Potential
sections: EQUIPOTENTIAL SURFACES AND THE ELECTRIC FIELD
POTENTIAL DUE TO A CHARGED PARTICLE
POTENTIAL DUE TO AN ELECTRIC DIPOLE
POTENTIAL DUE TO A CONTINUOUS CHARGE DISTRIBUTION
CALCULATING THE FIELD FROM THE POTENTIAL

ELECTRIC POTENTIAL ENERGY OF A S YSTEM OF 
CHARGED PARTICLES
POTENTIAL OF A CHARGED ISOLATED CONDUCTOR
chapters.summary: Chapter 24 covers electric potential, equipotential surfaces, potential due to charged particles, dipoles, and continuous charge distributions. It also discusses calculating the field from the potential and the electric potential energy of systems of charged particles.

chapters.title: Capacitance
sections: CAPACITORS IN PARALLEL AND IN SERIES
ENERGY STORED IN AN ELECTRIC FIELD
chapters.summary: Chapter 25 discusses capacitance, including calculating capacitance, capacitors in parallel and series, energy stored in an electric field, capacitors with dielectrics, and dielectrics and Gauss' Law.

chapters.title: Current and Resistance
chapters.summary: Chapter 26 covers electric current, current density, resistance and resistivity, Ohm's law, power in electric circuits, semiconductors, and superconductors.

chapters.title: Circuits
chapters.summary: Chapter 27 discusses circuits, including single-loop circuits, multiloop circuits, ammeters and voltmeters, and RC circuits.

chapters.title: Magnetic Fields
sections: MAGNETIC FIELDS AND THE DEFINITION OF B
CROSSED FIELDS: DISCOVERY OF THE ELECTRON
MAGNETIC FORCE ON A CURRENT-CARRYING WIRE
chapters.summary: Chapter 28 covers magnetic fields, including the definition of B, crossed fields and the discovery of the electron, the Hall effect, circulating charged particles, cyclotrons and synchrotrons, magnetic force on current-carrying wires, torque on current loops, and the magnetic dipole moment.

chapters.title: Magnetic Fields Due to Currents
sections: MAGNETIC FIELD DUE TO A CURRENT
A CURRENT-CARRYING COIL AS A MAGNETIC DIPOLE
chapters.summary: Chapter 29 discusses magnetic fields due to currents, including calculating the magnetic field, force between parallel currents, Ampere's Law, solenoids and toroids, and current-carrying coils as magnetic dipoles.

chapters.title: Induction and Inductance
sections: ENERGY STORED IN A MAGNETIC FIELD
ENERGY DENSITY OF A MAGNETIC FIELD
chapters.summary: Chapter 30 covers induction and inductance, including Faraday's Law and Lenz's Law, induction and energy transfers, induced electric fields, inductors and inductance, self-induction, RL circuits, energy stored in a magnetic field, energy density, and mutual induction.

chapters.title: Electromagnetic Oscillations and Alternating Current
sections: DAMPED OSCILLATIONS IN AN RLC CIRCUIT
FORCED OSCILLATIONS OF THREE SIMPLE CIRCUITS
chapters.summary: Chapter 31 discusses electromagnetic oscillations and alternating current, including LC oscillations, damped oscillations in RLC circuits, forced oscillations of simple circuits, series RLC circuits, power in AC circuits, and transformers.

chapters.title: Maxwell’s Equations; Magnetism of Matter
chapters.summary: Chapter 32 covers Maxwell's equations and the magnetism of matter, including Gauss' Law for magnetic fields, induced magnetic fields, displacement current, magnets, magnetism and electrons, diamagnetism, paramagnetism, and ferromagnetism.

chapters.title: Electromagnetic Waves
sections: ENERGY TRANSPORT AND THE P OYNTING VECTOR
chapters.summary: Chapter 33 discusses electromagnetic waves, including energy transport and the Poynting vector, radiation pressure, polarization, reflection and refraction, total internal reflection, and polarization by reflection.

chapters.title: Images
chapters.summary: Chapter 34 covers images, including plane mirrors, spherical mirrors, spherical refracting surfaces, thin lenses, and optical instruments.

chapters.title: Interference
chapters.summary: Chapter 35 discusses interference, including light as a wave, Young's interference experiment, double-slit interference, interference from thin films, and Michelson's interferometer.

chapters.title: Diffraction
chapters.summary: Chapter 36 discusses diffraction, including single-slit diffraction, intensity in single-slit diffraction, diffraction by a circular aperture, diffraction by a double slit, diffraction gratings, dispersion and resolving power of gratings, and X-ray diffraction.

chapters.title: Relativity
chapters.summary: Chapter 37 covers relativity, including simultaneity and time dilation, the relativity of length, the Lorentz transformation, the relativity of velocities, the Doppler effect for light, and momentum and energy.

chapters.title: Photons and Matter Waves
sections: THE PHOTON, THE QUANTUM OF LIGHT

PHOTONS, MOMENTUM, COMPTON SCATTERING, LIGHT 
INTERFERENCE
THE BIRTH OF QUANTUM PHY SICS
chapters.summary: Chapter 38 discusses photons and matter waves, including the photon as a quantum of light, the photoelectric effect, photons and momentum, Compton scattering, light interference, the birth of quantum physics, electrons and matter waves, Schrödinger’s equation, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, reflection from a potential step, and tunneling through a potential barrier.

chapters.title: More About Matter Waves
sections: WAVE FUNCTIONS OF A TRAPPED ELECTRON
AN ELECTRON IN A FINITE WELL
chapters.summary: Chapter 39 covers more about matter waves, including energies of a trapped electron, wave functions of a trapped electron, an electron in a finite well, two- and three-dimensional electron traps, and the hydrogen atom.

chapters.title: All About Atoms
sections: EXCLUSION PRINCIPLE AND MULTIPLE ELECTRONS IN A TRAP
X RAYS AND THE ORDERING OF THE ELEMENTS
chapters.summary: Chapter 40 discusses atoms, including properties of atoms, the Stern-Gerlach experiment, magnetic resonance, the exclusion principle and multiple electrons in a trap, building the periodic table, X-rays and the ordering of the elements, and lasers.

chapters.title: Conduction of Electricity in Solids
sections: THE p-n JUNCTION AND THE TRANSISTOR
chapters.summary: Chapter 41 covers conduction of electricity in solids, including the electrical properties of metals, semiconductors and doping, and the p-n junction and the transistor.

chapters.title: Nuclear Physics
chapters.summary: Chapter 42 discusses nuclear physics, including discovering the nucleus, some nuclear properties, radioactive decay, alpha decay, beta decay, radioactive dating, measuring radiation dosage, and nuclear models.

chapters.title: Energy from the Nucleus
sections: THERMONUCLEAR FUSION IN THE SUN AND OTHER STARS
chapters.summary: Chapter 43 covers energy from the nucleus, including nuclear fission, the nuclear reactor, a natural nuclear reactor, thermonuclear fusion, thermonuclear fusion in the sun and other stars, and controlled thermonuclear fusion.

chapters.title: Quarks, Leptons, and the Big Bang
chapters.summary: Chapter 44 discusses quarks, leptons, and the Big Bang, including general properties of elementary particles, leptons, hadrons, strangeness, quarks and messenger particles, and cosmology.
